affirmation: I embrace that the only true wisdom is knowing that I know nothing.
I live an examined life, for the unexamined life is not worth living.
I recognize that virtue is knowledge, and through wisdom I become good.
I question everything, for questioning leads to understanding.
I know myself, for self-knowledge is the beginning of all wisdom.
I cannot teach anyone anything; I can only help them think for themselves.
I find that there is only one good - knowledge, and one evil - ignorance.
I am kind to everyone, for each person I meet is fighting a hard battle.
I let wonder be the beginning of my wisdom.
I think for myself to find myself.
I understand that no one does wrong willingly; all evil comes from ignorance.
I value not life itself, but living rightly and well.
I seek beauty in the inward soul and align my outer and inner self.
I acknowledge my intellectual humility and remain open to learning.
I discuss ideas with strong minds rather than gossip about people.
I understand that education kindles a flame rather than filling a vessel.
I am slow to fall into friendship, but once in, I remain firm and constant.
I find happiness not in seeking more, but in developing capacity to enjoy less.
I move myself first before attempting to move the world.
I see contentment as natural wealth and luxury as artificial poverty.
I understand that death may be the greatest of all human blessings.
I improve myself through others' writings, learning from their labor.
I treat others as I would wish to be treated myself.
I recognize that every action has both its pleasures and its price.
I am a citizen of the world, not bound by narrow nationalism.
I understand that false words infect the soul with evil.
I do not return injury for injury, for it is never right to do injustice.
I live beautifully, justly, and well as one unified existence.
I desire wisdom and insight as urgently as I desire to breathe.
I maintain physical fitness, for it is shameful to neglect my body's potential.
I examine my beliefs through dialogue and questioning.
I admit my ignorance as the first step toward true knowledge.
I care more for my soul than for my body or possessions.
I define myself by my character and actions, not external things.
I question authority and accepted wisdom to find truth.
I understand that an unexamined assumption is a dangerous foundation.
I practice self-control as a form of wisdom and knowledge.
I seek to understand the nature of justice through inquiry and dialogue.
I accept that I may be wrong and remain open to correction.
I measure my worth by my virtue, not by worldly success.
I use reason as my guide in all moral decisions.
I understand that courage is knowledge of what to fear and what not to fear.
I practice temperance as knowledge of proper measure in all things.
I see piety as right relationship with the divine through virtue.
I acknowledge that my soul is more valuable than my body.
I prefer to suffer injustice rather than commit it.
I trust that the divine sign within guides me away from error.
I understand that knowledge of good and evil is the highest knowledge.
I care for my soul through philosophical examination.
I see death as either eternal sleep or a journey to meet great souls.
I question my own beliefs as rigorously as I question others'.
I understand that wisdom consists in knowing the limits of my knowledge.
I practice dialectic to expose false beliefs and find truth.
I remain curious and maintain wonder about the world.
I understand that knowledge is recollection of eternal truths.
I see my role as a midwife helping others give birth to their own ideas.
I value the health of my soul above all material possessions.
I understand that true knowledge leads inevitably to virtuous action.
I examine my life daily to ensure I live according to reason.
I see ignorance as the root of all evil and vice.
I practice intellectual humility in all my interactions.
I understand that definitions reveal the essence of things.
I seek universal truths through particular examples and cases.
I believe that no evil can befall a good person, in life or death.
I understand that the gods are wise and good.
I practice philosophy as preparation for death.
I see contradiction as a sign that my understanding is incomplete.
I use irony to expose the false confidence of those who claim knowledge.
I understand that virtue cannot be taught like technical skills.
I seek to align my will with divine will through virtue.
I recognize that moral knowledge is different from technical knowledge.
I understand that the soul is the source of all knowledge and virtue.
I practice self-examination as my highest duty.
I see apparent contradictions as opportunities for deeper understanding.
I understand that true friendship is based on virtue and wisdom.
I accept that human wisdom is worth little compared to divine wisdom.
I see my mission as awakening others to examine their lives.
I understand that knowledge of ignorance is better than ignorant confidence.
I practice philosophy as a way of life, not just an academic discipline.
I see every conversation as an opportunity for mutual learning.
I understand that the care of the soul is my primary responsibility.
I recognize that ethical knowledge must be lived, not just understood.
I see wisdom as recognizing the difference between what I know and what I don't.
I understand that the examined life requires constant vigilance and effort.
I practice aporia - the productive confusion that leads to insight.
I see questioning as an act of love for truth and the person questioned.
I understand that moral improvement comes through self-knowledge.
I accept that true knowledge often reveals how much I don't know.
I see my ignorance as an opportunity for growth and learning.
I understand that virtue is its own reward and needs no external validation.
I practice intellectual courage in questioning popular beliefs.
I see philosophy as medicine for the soul's ailments.
I understand that wisdom begins with acknowledging my limitations.
I seek truth through collaborative inquiry rather than debate.
I recognize that learning requires admitting what I don't understand.
I understand that the divine has given me reason to use for good.
I see every mistake as a teacher pointing toward truth.
I practice philosophy to become a better person, not just more knowledgeable.
I understand that the pursuit of wisdom is a lifelong journey.
I live each day examining my thoughts, beliefs, and actions for truth and virtue.
